document_title: The rapid diagnosis and effective inhibition of coronavirus using spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles
summary_full: This study presents the development of gold nanoparticles (GNPs) functionalized with anti-spike antibodies for the rapid diagnosis and inhibition of SARS-CoV-2. The GNPs exhibit a colorimetric change from pink to blue upon aggregation in the presence of COVID-19 antigen or pseudo SARS-CoV-2, allowing for naked-eye detection within 5 minutes at concentrations of 1 ng/mL for antigen and 1000 particles/mL for virus. For enhanced sensitivity, Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) was employed, achieving detection limits of 4 pg/mL for antigen and 18 particles/mL for virus within the same timeframe. FDTD simulations indicated a 4-orders-of-magnitude Raman enhancement in nanoparticle aggregates. Furthermore, the anti-spike antibody-coated GNPs demonstrated a 100% inhibition efficiency against pseudo SARS-CoV-2 infection in HEK293T cells by blocking viral entry and potentially damaging the viral lipid membrane.
key_findings: Developed anti-spike antibody-attached gold nanoparticles for rapid colorimetric detection of COVID-19 antigen and pseudo SARS-CoV-2 within 5 minutes.
Achieved highly sensitive detection using SERS with limits of detection of 4 pg/mL for antigen and 18 virus particles/mL for pseudo SARS-CoV-2.
Demonstrated 100% inhibition of pseudo SARS-CoV-2 infection in HEK293T cells using the antibody-functionalized gold nanoparticles.
FDTD simulations predicted a 4-orders-of-magnitude Raman enhancement in nanoparticle aggregates, explaining SERS sensitivity.
The assay showed high selectivity for COVID-19 spike antigen over SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV antigens.
future_research_fields: Development of point-of-care diagnostic devices utilizing the SERS-based gold nanoparticle probe.
In vivo studies to evaluate the therapeutic potential and safety of antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles for COVID-19 inhibition.
Exploration of different nanoparticle materials and antibody designs for improved diagnostic sensitivity and broader antiviral applications.
Investigation into the precise mechanisms of viral membrane disruption by antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles.
Application of this platform for the detection and inhibition of other viral pathogens.
related_papers: Ventura et al. reported highly sensitive COVID-19 detection by means of a colorimetric assay that employed GNPs to which three different (spike, envelope, and membrane) antibodies were attached.
Liu et al. reported antibody attached GNP-based influenza A virus detection.
Abbott Real Time SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR assay (40 copies per mL).
conclusions: Anti-spike antibody-attached gold nanoparticles offer a promising platform for both rapid, sensitive diagnosis of COVID-19 antigens and pseudo SARS-CoV-2, and for effective inhibition of viral infection. The colorimetric and SERS-based detection methods are fast and highly selective, while the nanoparticles demonstrate significant antiviral activity by blocking viral entry and damaging the viral membrane.
impact_statement: This research provides a dual-purpose nanotechnology platform for rapid COVID-19 diagnosis and potential therapeutic intervention, addressing critical needs during the pandemic.
